title: Woman Abuse Screening Tool (WAST)
description: Validated screening instrument for detecting intimate partner violence (domestic abuse) in women in healthcare settings. The WAST uses 8 questions to assess past and current relationship dynamics, emotional and physical abuse patterns, and immediate safety concerns. This evidence-based tool helps healthcare providers identify women experiencing domestic violence in clinical settings.

parameters.name: tension_arguments_relationship
parameters.description: In general, how would you describe your relationship? (1=lots of tension, 2=some tension, 3=no tension)

parameters.name: partner_jealousy_possessiveness
parameters.description: Do you and your partner work out arguments with: (1=great difficulty, 2=some difficulty, 3=no difficulty)

parameters.name: arguments_resolution
parameters.description: Do arguments ever result in you feeling down or bad about yourself? (1=often, 2=sometimes, 3=never)

parameters.name: arguments_feeling_bad
parameters.description: Do arguments ever result in hitting, kicking or pushing? (1=often, 2=sometimes, 3=never)

parameters.name: physical_violence_frequency
parameters.description: Do you ever feel frightened by what your partner says or does? (1=often, 2=sometimes, 3=never)

parameters.name: feel_frightened
parameters.description: Has your partner ever abused you physically? (1=yes, 2=no)

parameters.name: physical_abuse_history
parameters.description: Has your partner ever abused you emotionally? (1=yes, 2=no)

parameters.name: emotional_abuse_history
parameters.description: Has your partner ever abused you sexually? (1=yes, 2=no)

result.name: wast_score
result.description: WAST total score indicating domestic violence risk level

ranges.description: High probability of intimate partner violence
ranges.interpretation: Score indicates high likelihood of domestic violence. Immediate safety assessment and intervention planning required. Provide resources, safety planning, and appropriate referrals to domestic violence services.

ranges.description: Moderate probability of intimate partner violence
ranges.interpretation: Score suggests possible intimate partner violence. Further assessment recommended. Provide information about domestic violence resources and support services. Consider follow-up screening.

ranges.description: Low probability of intimate partner violence
ranges.interpretation: Score indicates low likelihood of domestic violence. Continue routine care. Provide general information about healthy relationships if appropriate.

references: Brown JB, Lent B, Brett PJ, Sas G, Pederson LL. Development of the Woman Abuse Screening Tool for use in family practice. Fam Med. 1996;28(6):422-428.
Brown JB, Lent B, Schmidt G, Sas G. Application of the Woman Abuse Screening Tool (WAST) and WAST-short in the family practice setting. J Fam Pract. 2000;49(10):896-903.
MacMillan HL, Wathen CN, Jamieson E, et al. Screening for intimate partner violence in health care settings: a randomized trial. JAMA. 2009;302(5):493-501. doi: 10.1001/jama.2009.1089
Rabin RF, Jennings JM, Campbell JC, Bair-Merritt MH. Intimate partner violence screening tools: a systematic review. Am J Prev Med. 2009;36(5):439-445.e4. doi: 10.1016/j.amepre.2009.01.024
formula: Sum of scores for 8 intimate partner violence screening questions. Questions 1-5 scored 1-3 points (1=highest risk), Questions 6-8 scored 1-2 points (1=yes=highest risk). Total score ranges from 8-24 points, with lower scores indicating higher risk of intimate partner violence.
notes: Validated for use in healthcare settings to screen for intimate partner violence
Should be administered in private, confidential setting without partner present
Lower scores indicate higher risk of domestic violence
Questions 1-5 assess relationship dynamics and emotional impact
Questions 6-8 assess history of physical, emotional, and sexual abuse
Requires training for appropriate administration and response
Should be integrated with safety planning and resource provision
Not intended for use in emergency situations where immediate safety is at risk
Consider cultural and linguistic factors when administering
Follow institutional protocols for positive screens and mandatory reporting
Provide trauma-informed care principles during screening
Ensure confidentiality and safety of screening process
Have domestic violence resources readily available
Consider repeat screening as relationship dynamics may change
Document findings appropriately per institutional policy
Be prepared to provide immediate safety interventions if needed
